metadata.title: Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injury  Prevention
description: ACL strain or rupture is a common knee injury, although rarely an isolated injury as the medial collateral ligament (MCL), medial meniscus, and tibial plateau are often affected
The ACL-deficient  knee is at increased risk for anterior displacement of the tibia(16)
There are several programs focusing on the prevention of ACL injuries. Because of increased incidence of ACL injury in female athletes, many of the prevention programs are focused on this population

Categories of risk factors associated with ACL injury that should be addressed in prevention programs include environmental, biomechanical, anatomical, and neuromuscular, as well as type of activity or sport

ICD-10 codes.Z71.9: Counseling unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement for an ACL prevention program has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Athlete in high-risk  sports (e.g., soccer, basketball, handball, volleyball, skiing). Knee laxity or deficits in lower extremity strength and coordination may have been identified Causes, Risk Factors, and Pathomechanics of the ACL- Deficient Knee

overall contraindications precautions: If a patient has had ACL surgery within the past year, he or she should obtain clearance from the surgeon for participation in an ACL injury prevention program

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury -If an injury has already occurred, document the date of injury. During what activity did the injury occur? Any specifics regarding mechanism of injury? -Did other symptoms accompany the injury, such as “pop,” “giving way,” “catch,” “lock,” or “snap”? -A “pop” heard or felt at the time of injury may indicate ACL sprain, meniscal tear, or fracture -A “crunch” may indicate a medial meniscal tear -A tearing sensation may indicate a collateral ligament injury -Did swelling occur immediately after the injury? -Immediate  may indicate hemarthrosis from fracture or cruciate ligament tear -Few hours later  may indicate an intraarticular lesion (e.g., meniscus tear)T708741 and Clinical Review…Pediatric ; Item Number and treatment of the injured and surgically repaired ACL

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management What has been the course of intervention to date if applicable? Conservative treatment (e.g., bracing, rest, ice)? Joint aspiration? Surgical intervention? If so, describe
course of treatment.medications: Is the patient taking any medication for pain? NSAIDs are often prescribed
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Has the patient had a recent X-ray,  MRI, or arthroscopy of the knee?
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture), the reason for their use, and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy related to knee injury, and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Use the Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) or Lysholm scale for functional outcome measures
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Vague pain in the anterior knee made worse by stairs, squatting, kneeling, or prolonged flexion suggestive of patellofemoral pain (most common cause), but also seen in osteochondritis dissecans and recurrent patellar subluxation (very severe) -Medial knee pain may involve other causes such as medial collateral ligament sprain -Meniscal tears often produce posterior knee pain
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Other symptoms -Are there any signs of inflammation (e.g., swelling, redness, warmth)? -Does the patient report locking of the knee? -Locked = knee can't be fully extended due to a physical block -Typically due to a torn meniscus  refer to appropriate physician within 24 hours -Does the patient report the following? -Catching or clicking  may indicate a loose body, torn meniscus, and/or degenerative joint disease -Snapping  may indicate inflamed synovial plica -Knee giving way? Sensation of instability? -Occasional giving way is common with patellofemoral pain or symptomatic degenerative joint disease -True giving way may occur with subluxing patella, a loose body due to previous trauma or osteochondritis dissecans, torn meniscus, or chronic ligamentous instability -Grating sensation/patellofemoral pain  may indicate degenerative joint disease -Inquire about other joint involvement Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: History of knee pain or injury? Individuals with a history of ACL injury are at high risk for future reinjuries
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Obtain a thorough history of training and competition schedule, including any increases in frequency or intensity. What risk factors for ACL injury does the patient have?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Is there any impairment in ADLs noted?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Anthropometric measurements: Girth measurements for swelling. Assess BMI. Evaluate leg lengths
relevant tests and measures.balance: Complete a thorough standing balance assessment. Note any asymmetry or compensations due to trunk or gluteal muscle weakness Functional tests –Assess patient’s ability to independently and safely complete transfers and stair negotiation –Assess how athlete completes a vertical jump test, bilateral jump and land, single-leg  hop test, broad jump test, and any other sport-specific  skills (as indicated) -Note angle of the trunk, knee, and hip position
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait and note deviations and asymmetry. Assess running as indicatedAssess lateral collateral and medial collateral ligament integrity; assess patella mobility; assess medial and lateral meniscal integrity. Note any asymmetry or abnormality. Does the patient report any pain with joint testing?
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete manual muscle testing (MMT) of lower extremities and compare. Assess ability to perform a straight leg raise in supine. Note the presence of an extensor lag at the knee
observation inspection palpation includi: Is edema, swelling, or visible bruising/skin discoloration present?
Is there pain on palpation of soft tissue structure? Document location
relevant tests and measures.posture: Observe for genu valgum, genu varum, locking of knees in stance or knee hyperextension. Complete full standing posture assessment in addition to evaluating subtalar neutral in non-weight-bearing  position
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess bilateral lower extremity ROM. Note any restriction due to pain or mechanical block –Decreased range of hip internal rotation can increase the susceptibility to ACL injury during pivoting activities(7)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Lachman test(21) -Characterized by the most direct way to assess the status of the ACL -Patient in supine, knee flexed 20-30º,  thigh stabilized by one hand, and tibia translated anteriorly on femur with opposite hand -Degree of translation and end feel are noted; results are compared to the nonaffected side -Test is graded (0 to 4+) and considered positive if there is excessive anterior translation of the tibia on the femur -Indicates torn anterior cruciate ligament –The pivot shift test(22) -The patient is in supine -The knee is flexed from 0°(full extension) to 90°, while applying an external rotation stress to the tibia and a valgus force to the knee -Test is positive if there is a rapid anterior subluxation of the tibia at 20-30°  of flexion –McMurray’s test (for meniscal injury)(23) -The patient is in supine, knee completely flexed, with the tibia shifted into external or internal rotation -Clinician’s fingers are placed on joint line, tibial rotation is held steady, and the knee is extended slightly to ~90º -A positive test result – if a click is felt through palpation of the joint line and pain is felt during this maneuver –Posterior drawer sign (for PCL injury)(19) -The patient is in supine, knee flexed to 90º -Assess for increased posterior tibial translation when compared to uninjured extremity –Anterior drawer sign (for ACL injury)(20) -The patient in supine, knee flexed to 90º -Assess for increased anterior tibial translation when compared to uninjured extremity –Landing Error Scoring System (LESS)(10) -Assesses a patient’s jump-landing  technique to identify errors when performing a bilateral drop vertical jump task -The patient performs a vertical jump task at a height of 30 cm with the patient requiring to land at a distance of 50% of their jump height, followed by performing an immediate maximal vertical jump -A lower score on the LESS is indicative of a better jump-landing  technique, indicating a reduced risk of ACL injuries -The LESS is favorable for use in the young athletic population, but is not as accurate with high-school and collegiate athletes

other: For patients who have had ACL surgery within the past year, obtain clearance from the surgeon before participation in an ACL injury prevention program
Monitor athlete’s form during exercises, emphasize jump landing with soft knees, maintaining knees shoulder width apart, and avoiding valgus collapse

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Please see Indications for ACL Injury Prevention Programs  above
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Successful implementation of these programs requires the collaboration of governing bodies, sports scientists, physicians, coaches, parents, and athletes
other considerations: Oral contraceptive can provide a protective effect on reducing ACL tears in those between the ages of 15-19.  Oral contraceptive use has been shown to reduce the rate of ACL tears by as much as 63%(3)

Participation in a hip-focused  injury prevention program can reduce the incidence of ACL injury in female collegiate basketball players(13) –Based on a prospective study that included 309 female basketball players
treatment summary: There is need for additional research to develop evidence-based training programs to teach youth safe and proper landing techniques to reduce the incidence of noncontact ACL injuries. Currently, research supports the importance of a comprehensive neuromuscular strength and conditioning program that is sport specific and age appropriate. Plyometric/ agility training, strength and power, neuromuscular control and endurance, and balance/proprioceptive training are fundamental components of ACL prevention programs
Plyometric training, neuromuscular strengthening programs, and strength traininghave been associated with decreased risk of ACL injury(4)

U.S. researchers assessing the effects of an ACL injury prevention program in 1,439 female high-school  athletes in a prospective study in 2006 did not find that a plyometric training program reduced risk of noncontact ACL injuries –Soccer, basketball, and volleyball players were randomized to a control group (862) or an ACL injury prevention program (577) –Participants in the prevention program participated in a 20-minute  plyometric-based  exercise program twice a week throughout their season in addition to their usual practices. The program emphasized proper mechanics of landing from a jump and deceleration when running –At the end of 2 seasons, there were 6 confirmed noncontact ACL injuries: 3 in the prevention group and 3 in the control group. The incidence of noncontact ACL injuries per 1,000 exposures was 0.167 in the prevention group and 0.078 in the control group, yielding an odds ratio of 2.05, which was not significant (p > 0.05) –The researchers concluded that the 20-minute  plyometric training did not reduce the risk of noncontact ACL injuries in female high-school  athletes. Other factors such as program compliance, neuromuscular strength, and agility were not analyzed

The F-MARC  11+ program may be a useful program to minimize the risk factors associated with ACL injury in preadolescent female soccer players. The F-MARC  11+ is an injury prevention program designed for players age 14+ that focuses on proper form and techniques during all exercise activities(12) –Fifty-one  female athletes between the ages of 10 and 12 were randomized to either the F-Marc  group (n = 28) or control group (n = 23) –The F-MARC  group performed 15 in-season  sessions 2x/week –Conclusions showed that players in the F-MARC  11+ program showed decreased risk factors, notably reduced peak kneel valgus moment, compared to those in the control group

Authors of a similar study on the F-MARC  11+ program have also concluded that this program can be more effective at reducing some of the risk factors associated with ACL injuries among preadolescent female athletes compared to just adolescent athletes. The program works to reduce knee valgus angle and moment during double-legged jump landing(15)

Authors of a retrospective study have suggested that a prevention program for reducing ACL injuries in male athletes may include the following(14): –Performing multi-directional  exercises such as the single-leg maneuver –Performing reactionary based activities under unexpected situations –Appropriate foot positioning –Type of playing surface –Enhance neuromuscular aspects that include fatigue, proprioception, muscle activation, and inter-joint coordination . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Low hamstrings-to- quadriceps strength ratioNormalize hamstrings- to-quadriceps strength ratioResistance training _ Address muscle strength imbalance (due to quadriceps dominance or limited hamstrings strength) and asymmetry in lower extremity strength due to leg dominanceProgress as indicated and appropriate for each unique patientInstruct the patient on a home exercise program that complements the physical therapy exercise program Impaired core strength Improve core strength Core strength training _ Incorporate functional, sport-specific core strengthening activities such as squats, lunges with and without rotation, and single leg activities such as the Star DrillProgress as indicated and appropriate for each unique patientInstruct the patient on a home exercise program that complements the physical therapy exercise program Impaired balance Improve balance Balance training _ Static and dynamic balance exercisesProgress from static to dynamic balance exercises with eyes open then with eyes closedInstruct the patient on a home exercise program that complements the physical therapy exercise program Poor technique during sports-related movements, poor neuromuscular controlImprove technique and neuromuscular control during sports-related movementsFunctional training _ Neuromuscular training programs may decrease the risk of noncontact ACL injuries in female athletes _ _ Good technique: Symmetric foot position; knees over toes; knees flexed; chest over kneesProgress from 2-leg to 1-leg jumps, single to multiple jumps, jumps in place to hops and skips, always placing emphasis on good technique _ It is not established what the minimum duration of an ACL injury prevention program is or whether it needs to be continued, and at what frequency, throughout the athletic season. It typically takes about 4–6 weeks before any benefit for the athlete can be noted. Many programs have an intense start- up period for about 6 weeks followed by less frequent or no additional training _ _Instruct the patient on a home exercise program that complements the physical therapy exercise program  .

reduction of acl injuries: Time off sport due to injury
improved strength, flexibility, balance,: MMT, ROM and flexibility assessment, balance assessment

patient education: ACL Injuries Prevention, WebMD website, http://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/anterior-cruciate-ligament-acl-injuries-prevention Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
